newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP says to be led by two chairmen.
newsitem.headline: SAP says to be led by two chairmen.

text.p: German software group SAP AG said on Wednesday it would in future be led by two management board chairmen with the current deputy stepping up to share the top post.

SAP said in a statement that Hasso Plattner, deputy management board chairman, would join Dietmar Hopp as a co-chairman of the company in a move necessitated by SAP's rapid growth and expansion overseas.
Calling Plattner his close friend, Hopp said the move to a "two-chairmen" management structure suited SAP's corporate culture and its "flat" chain of command.

SAP also said in the statement that pre-tax profit soared 56 percent to 582 million marks during the first half of this year while sales during the same period climbed 51 percent to 2.4 billion marks.
The company, a favorite among American investors, also said it would not list its shares in the U.S. any earlier than the end of 1998.
The company had previously reported that profit growth would be similar to the first quarter's 54 percent growth rate.
In the first quarter, SAP benefitted from the strength of the dollar as about a third of its sales are from the U.S. market.
The dollar now stands at an eight-year high of around 1.83 marks, even higher than the 1.67 rate at the end of the first quarter.
